titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Nina Wilcox Putnam Papers
titlestmt.author: by Michael L. Forstrom

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:30

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Nina Wilcox Putnam papers contain writings, correspondence, and other materials documenting the life and work of feminist and author Nina Wilcox Putnam. Writings consists chiefly of drafts of short stories and essays dating from the 1930s onward. There are drafts of a few novels, possibly unpublished, and a number of treatments, but the collection does not include material relating to Putnam's longer published works, or her children's book Sunny Bunny (1917), dating from the first two decades of her literary career. Correspondence consists of a small number letters with editors, publishers, and others dating from the early 1950s. The largest file exists for The Reader's Digest, but there are also letters from Gilbert Roland, Frank Scully, and Gloria Swanson. In addition, there are carbons of several outgoing letters dating from 1953 relating to an article by Putnam on Guatemala. Other materials include lists of works by Putnam documenting titles by genre and publisher.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English; some material in Spanish.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Nina Wilcox Putnam Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Nina Wilcox Putnam Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Preliminary processing was done to the Nina Wilcox Putnam papers at an unknown date. During reprocessing of the collection in 2010, the arrangement of writings and correspondence was largely preserved in Series I and II, and other materials were consolidated in Series III.

bioghist.head: Nina Wilcox Putnam (1888-1962)
bioghist.p: Nina Wilcox Putnam, author, was born in New Haven, Connecticut, the daughter of Marrion Wilcox, a professor of English at Yale, and Eleanor Patricia Sanchez. Putnam was educated at home and published her first piece, a short story, in 1907. She married Robert Faulkner Putnam of the publishing family in 1907; Robert J. Sanderson, a businessman, in 1919; Arthur James Ogle, a Florida real estate agent, in 1931; and Christian Eliot in 1933. Putnam published over twenty books, including novels, children's books, and non-fiction works, and a great many short stories and articles. Summary information is available in the standard biographical resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Nina Wilcox Putnam papers contain writings, correspondence, and personal papers documenting the life and work of feminist and author Nina Wilcox Putnam. Writings consist chiefly of drafts of short stories and essays dating from the 1930s onward. There are drafts of a few novels, possibly unpublished, and a number of treatments, but the collection does not include material relating to Putnam's longer published works, or her children's book Sunny Bunny (1917), dating from the first two decades of her literary career. Correspondence consists of a small number letters to and from editors, publishers, and others dating from the early 1950s. The largest file exists for The Reader's Digest , but there are also letters from Gilbert Roland, Frank Scully, and Gloria Swanson. In addition, there are carbons of several outgoing letters dating from 1953 relating to an article by Putnam on Guatemala. Other materials include lists of works by Putnam documenting titles by genre and publisher.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Writings, 1929-1959. II. Correspondence, 1940-1962. Personal Papers, 1953-1954.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title (in quotes) or supplied heading (in brackets).

Series I, Writings, consists chiefly of drafts of short stories and essays dating from the 1930s onward. There are drafts of a few novels, possibly unpublished, and a number of treatments, but the series does not include material relating to Putnam's longer published works, or her children's book Sunny Bunny (1917), dating from the first two decades of her literary career. Most drafts are typed and many are corrected. In addition to the genre, only the presence of multiple drafts and other physical formats (e.g. "holograph") are noted in folder headings below.
Many drafts in the series have the name and address of Putnam's literary agents, Jacques Chambrun and others, on the front cover or first page.
Publication dates have been preserved as bracketed circa dates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Correspondence, consists of a small number letters to and from editors, publishers, and others dating from the early 1950s. The largest correspondence file exists for The Reader's Digest , but there are also letters from Gilbert Roland, Frank Scully, and Gloria Swanson. In addition, there are carbons of several outgoing letters dating from 1953 relating to Putnam's article "Who's to Blame in Guatemala".

did.physloc: Also stored in: Oversize, broadside cabinets, container 11

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Personal Papers, contains lists of works by Putnam and manuscript notes. The lists document Putnam's work by genre and publisher.
